meanings.definition: To remove a load or burden from a person or vehicle.
meanings.sent1: I helped my friend offload the heavy boxes from his car.
meanings.sent2: The workers offload the cargo from the ship onto the dock.
meanings.sent3: After a long day at work, I offload my stress by taking a relaxing bath.
meanings.sent4: She offloaded her worries onto her journal, feeling lighter afterwards.
meanings.sent5: The image of the mountain offloading its snow is a sight to behold.

meanings.definition: To transfer goods or responsibilities to someone else.
meanings.sent1: The manager asked me to offload the task to my colleague.
meanings.sent2: Parents often offload household chores to their children.
meanings.sent3: I tried to offload my homework onto my dog, but he just wagged his tail.
meanings.sent4: She offloaded the project to her team, trusting them to handle it well.
meanings.sent5: The captain decided to offload the decision-making to his first mate.

meanings.definition: To sell or dispose of goods or assets.
meanings.sent1: The company needed to offload excess inventory to make space for new products.
meanings.sent2: He decided to offload his old car before buying a new one.
meanings.sent3: She tried to offload her old clothes at the garage sale, but no one wanted them.
meanings.sent4: The businessman offloaded his shares in the company before the stock market crashed.
meanings.sent5: The farmer offloaded his harvest at the market to earn a profit.
